items.title: KPCC for iPad
items.teaser: Product design for KPCC's native tablet app.
items.description: The flagship iPad app for KPCC, public radio for Southern California. The app positions KPCC as a digital news leader in Los Angeles, and connects our audiences to the public radio they love.

gallery.caption: Users can select their favorite programs and have new episodes automatically added to their queue.
Articles look their best on KPCC for iPad, with gorgeous images and elegant typography. Slideshows, video and audio are always just a tap away.
Audio is surfaced throughout the app, making it easy to discover, queue and play radio segments and episodes.
The app takes full advantage of iPad's canvas to show off the Short List's tightly curated sets of stories and beautiful photography.

items.problem:
With the second-largest newsroom in Los Angeles and dozens of articles published every day, KPCC needed a product that positioned it as a news brand that delivered more than just great radio.

Focusing on the tablet as a great device for reading, we wondered if we could build a product that would draw our audience in with a great listening experience, but also create addictive reading habits.

And since our most loyal fans were likely to seek out a KPCC native app, we wanted to find ways to deepen the emotional connection with our brand, building increased loyalty that could drive membership.

outcomes.item: Created a new editorial feature, The Short List, delivering curated editions of the day's news to iPad users in the early morning and late afternoon.

KPCC for iPad is the first product to succeessfully switch KPCC's loyal listeners to readers. Users read an average of more thant 2 stories per session, and engage in reading seven times more often than listening.
Built a product that users love: 94% 5-star ratings in the first 30 days, and more than 50% of active users use the app multiple times per day.

items.title: Half In Ten
items.teaser: A redesign of poverty data visualizations for Center for American Progress.
items.description: The Center for American Progress has been workoing to reduce poverty by 50% in the U.S. by 2020 - a project they call Half in Ten. As part of that effort, CAP needed to rethink the way they visualized povery data to maximize its impact and catalyze action.

gallery.caption: Breakdowns by state allow you to see at a glance how your state compares to the rest of the U.S. Carefully selected icons add impact to each indicator.
Informmation priorities on each page were carefully considered so that top-line numbers are clear at a glance on any device.
A new landing page concept was created to give users clear points of entry and provide additional context and narrative in support of Half In Ten's misison.
As the user reaches the end of the page, clear calls to action and resources get advocates engaged in the fight to reduce poverty in their city or state.

items.problem:
The Center for American Progress has been workoing to reduce poverty by 50% in the U.S. by 2020 - a project they call Half in Ten. As part of that effort, CAP needed to rethink the way they visualized povery data to maximize its impact and catalyze action.

Half In Ten's leadership team identified a clear set of challenges. Their current visualizations were hard to follow and didn't tell a clear story. Also, while the charts and graphs looked good on desktops, they needed a solution that commiunicated poverty data with equal impact across all devices and screens. And finally, they wanted to use their data to reinforce the powerful story of poverty in the U.S., and catalyze users to act.

outcomes.item: Through improved balance, heirarchy and copywriting, redesigned pages help the data speak more powerfully by bringing much-needed clarity in the relationships between data points.
Wireframes were created for large and small screens, reimagining complex charts for effective display on smartphones and other personal devices.
The new design increases the visibility of state-level breakdowns, giving users a better sense of how their state is trending over time, and compared to other states in the U.S.

items.title: KPCC.org Redesign
items.teaser: A responsive redesign for Southern California Public Radio.
items.description: KPCC is the second largest public radio station in the U.S., and the second-largest newsroom in Los Angeles. To serve the daily news needs of a major metropolis, KPCC's website was redesigned responsively and rebuilt from the ground up.

gallery.caption: In addition to supporting a large-scale daily newsgathering operation, great care was also taken to shine a spotlight on KPCC's live community events platform.
KPCC's homepage not only responds to the daily news cycle, but also can adapt to focus on major events like the results of the 2012 presidential election.
On small screens, an unobtrusive off-canvas navigation provides access to all of KPCC's news and program content, as well as a point of entry to KPCC's donation form.
Across the site, multiple content types are presented in a unified interface: blog posts, radio segments, live events and visual journalism all coexist on thei KPCC homepage.

items.services: Product strategy, Product design, front-end development
items.problem:
My first major project when I arrived at KPCC was to rethink and redesign KPCC's website from the ground up. The orgnaization was in the midst of transformational change, attempting to merge its radio and digital editorial operations. It was also growing like crazy, doubling the size of its newsroom in less than a year.

As we embarked on the project in late 2011, KPCC's goals were manifold: it needed to refresh its digital brand, serve audiences across devices, continue to serve loyal radio listeners, and establish itself as a premiere news brand in Los Angeles.

outcomes.item: By focusing on de-siloing the many types of content KPCC publishes, and designing to support a large volume of daily journalism, the redesign bolstered KPCC.org as it grew from a half-million monthly visits to over 1 million monthly visits in 12 months.

Launched in May 2012, KPCC's responsive design positioned it to support a proliferation of smartphones and tablets. Total share of traffic coming from mobile devices has increased from 20% (May '12) to 42% (Dec '13).
The first public media organization to launch a responsive website, KPCC.org received numerous national design awards from the journalism and publishing industry.

items.title: KPCC Email Newsletters
items.teaser: A visual system and front-end solution for mobile-friendly email newsletters.
items.description: A visual overhaul and responsive redesign of all KPCC's email templates, along with a front-end project that makes HTML emails a pleasure to code.

gallery.caption: KPCC's email newsletters were redesigned and coded from scratch to ensure they look amazing on mobile devices.
Images and typography are responsive and scale up to larger screens and desktop email clients.
Design patterns are matched with front-end code patterns, allowing content creators to take a 'building block' approach to email creation.
A single visual design system unifies our communications across breaking news, regular newsletters and membership appeals.

items.problem:
Email is a critical channel for KPCC to communicate with its audience. From fundraising to breaking news, email helps KPCC fulfill its editorial mission and sustain its business.

With more than a half-million emails sent each month and over 40% of email opens happening on mobile devices, KPCC needed a complete overhaul of its email design system. The system needed to be modular, flexible and on-brand while also being responsive.

In addition to the design challenges of the project, anyone who's had to code HTML email will tell you it's painful. Very painful. Between gnarly nested tables and inline CSS, any sane developer would run screaming.

outcomes.item: Created a design system of reusable components and patterns that enabled email authors to assemble custom email campaigns.
Created a project with a sane front-end development workflow (SCSS, Slim, helpers), along with a build process to inline CSS and generate battle-tested HTML email that's ready to send.

items.title: LAUP Marketing Landing Page
items.teaser: A premium advertising experience for one of KPCC's corporate underwriters.
items.description: As part of an exclusive sponsorship of KPCC's education coverage, the responsive landing page for LA Universal Preschool goes beyond banner ads to deliver a premium experience for KPCC's audience and advertiser.

gallery.caption: After making an initial emotional impact, the landing page encourages users to launch a video that explains LAUP's values and mission.
The landing page draws users through LAUP's story, touching down on an email signup form so LAUP can communicate directly with KPCC's audience.
Cinematic background images bolster the copywriting and reinforce LAUP's focus on improving the educational futures of young children in Los Angeles.
The landing page is fully responsive, giving LAUP high-quality impressions across all devices.

items.problem:
Like most news organizations, KPCC is trying to go beyond banner ads to find new forms of digital ad revenue that are sustainable, lucrative, and provide a better user experience.

So when LA Universal Preschool expressed interest in being the exclusive sponsor of KPCC's education coverage for an entire year, we knew we needed to design a solution that gave LAUP unique exposure, while remaining true to KPCC's member-supported, mission-driven values and ethics.

Finding the right solution required us to move into uncharted territory, both for KPCC and LAUP. Ensuring advertising impact while preserving the clear distinction between advertising and editorial required close collaboration with KPCC's editorial leadership and the corporate underwriter.

outcomes.item: Designed a bespoke landing page as a destination for LAUP's campaign, creating unique ad inventory and enabling KPCC to secure premium sponsorship revenue.
Landing page includes an email signup conversation point, giving LAUP a direct way to engage with users that goes beyond impressions and clickthrough.

items.title: Highlander New Student Orientation
items.teaser: A UC Riverside webapp that guides incoming students through orientation registration.
items.description: UC Riverside requires all incoming students to attend Orientation, preparing them for the transition to college. To dramatically simplify a complex signup process, UCR needed a complete redesign of their online registration system.

gallery.caption: Highlander Orientation offers different sessions tailored to specific groups of students. The redesigned webapp makes it easy for students to chose the right session.
The form is broken up into multiple steps with discrete sections, contextual tips and validation, making a long and complex process seem less overwhelming.
Getting students to read the fine print about the Orientation experience is challenging. Conversational copywriting and good IA help bring important details to the fore.
Detailed wireframes were created to model the registration form's complex flows and decision logic, from signin to payment.

items.problem:
Navigating the college admissions process is downright frightening for many wide-eyed high school seniors. At UC Riverside, we knew that our in-person New Student Orientation sessions were of the most confusing parts of the process.

Deciding what session to attend, registering your parents for their own information sessions, reading the fine print, paying your fees, knowing what to bring for your overnight stay on campus...many students wound up arriving unprepared, or not attending Orientation at all.

UCR found that students who attend Orientation were far less likely to struggle during their freshman year, and also less likely to drop out. Radically simplifying the online Orientation registration process was deemed critical to the success of the program: UCR wants to create positive feelings in incoming students during these early touchpoints as students begin to form impressions of their new home.

outcomes.item: Designed the entire user journey through the registration process, from communication plans and email notifications down to every field in the multi-step form. Used user-centered approaches to shifted the design focus away from UCR's business process and toward students' needs.

Reviewed call center databases and identified the most common student pain points. Used this data to guide UI refinements to reduce confusion and guide students successfully through the registration form.

Introduced new visual design to bring increased clarity and structure to our webapps. The app's design focuses on making users feel confident and in control of the registration process, and subtly reinforces UCR's brand.
